Motorcycles are major contributors to air pollutants, i.e. CO, VOCs, and PM, emissions to the atmosphere in some regions around the world. Hydrothermal aging of the Pd-Pt-based wiremesh catalyst, as an emission control device for 4-stroke carburetor motorcycles, was studied under laboratory-simulated aging conditions. Aging temperature and reaction atmosphere were selected as independent variables affecting aging. Catalyst properties were characterized by ICP, XPS, BET, EDS, and FE-SEM analysis. Increasing aging temperature and oxidizing atmosphere led to a more pronounced particle size growth and sintering after aging. Regardless of the aging temperature, surface inhibition effects gradually disappeared by shifting the light-off curves to higher temperatures, whether the reason for this shift is oxygen deficiency in the reaction mixture or hydrothermal aging of the catalyst. The surface concentration of the most active phase of platinum, Pt0, decreased in the following order: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C ≈ reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. The overall trend of activity for different samples is as follows: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. The less extent of deactivation under reducing atmosphere was attributed to the preservation of metallic Pt content and limited particle size growth under such aging conditions. Analysis of the effect of the air-fuel ratio on the light-off profiles indicated that under all aging conditions, the rich atmosphere resulted in the highest degree of deactivation compared to stoichiometric and lean conditions. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Catalyst deactivation CO and propylene conversion Pt-Pd/Al2O3/CeO2/ZrO2 Motorcycle emission control Catalyst aging Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Air pollutants emitted from automotive exhaust gas contribute to global warming, ozone layer depletion, acid rain, and environmental toxicity [1,2]. Over 200 million motorcycles in-use around the world account for a significant portion of carbon monoxide (CO) and unburned hydrocarbons (HC) emissions [3,4]. Specifically, over one million motorcycles operating in the city of Tehran, the capital of Iran, are responsible for 31% of the total volatile organic compound (VOC), 15% of CO, and 12% of particulate matter (PM) emissions from mobile sources demonstrating their substantial contribution in air pollutants emissions in this city [5,6]. To meet strict environmental emission standards, exhaust aftertreatment catalysts need to maintain a high yield during the entire useful lifetime of motor vehicles. Despite significant improvements in catalytic converters technology during the last decades, catalyst deactivation due to poisoning and hydrothermal aging has always been a challenge [7]. Thermal aging is the major problem in the deactivation of automotive catalysts, where elevated temperatures, the presence of water vapor, and inconstant environmental conditions result in a series of processes leading to a loss of catalytic activity. Loss of specific surface area of the catalyst support, sintering of noble metal particles, and growth of the mixed oxides can decrease the effective contact between the gaseous species present in the exhaust gas and catalytic sites thus decreasing catalyst activity [8]. Oxidation catalysts, as an exhaust aftertreatment system for motorcycles, can reduce emissions of CO, VOC, and PM by 80%, 60%, and 50%, respectively [9]. Pt-Pd bimetallic catalysts are good candidates for oxidation catalysts, both in motorcycle applications and diesel applications as diesel oxidation catalysts (DOC), because of their superior oxidation performance. These bimetallic catalysts are susceptible to sintering when exposed to high temperatures. The effect of Hydrothermal aging on the performance of Pt-Pd-based catalysts, including DOC [7,10,11], three-way catalyst (TWC) [8,12], and methane oxidation catalyst (MOC) [13,14], have been previously investigated. TWCs typically contain Pt, Pd, and Rh as active phases, while Pt and Pd are the main active species in oxidation catalysts (eg. DOC and MOC) formulations. Alumina is the most common metal oxide in the DOC support formulation, while ceria-zirconia-alumina mixed oxides are typically used as aftertreatment catalyst support in stoichiometric combustion applications. Pt is observed to more readily sinter when subjected to hydrothermal aging compared to Pd supported on alumina [10]. Bimetallic Pt-Pd catalysts have been introduced as alternatives for Pt-only catalysts to enhance the thermal stability of metallic Pt [15,16]. The reduced Pt sites (metallic Pt phase) have been identified as the active sites for oxidation reactions [17–23]. Pd has higher thermal stability under oxidizing conditions compared to oxidized Pt, as the latter can form volatile PtO2; Therefore, Pt-Pd alloy has been introduced as an efficient catalyst formulation with enhanced hydrothermal stability [15,24–26]. Especially, the addition of Pd to Pt-based catalysts can suppress the formation of large Pt particles, which typically happens due to a vapor-phase transport of platinum during high-temperature treatment of Pt [15,24–27]. In contrast, Pd particles sinter more rapidly under reducing conditions [28], most likely due to the formation of metallic Pd that has a lower surface tension than PdO [29,30]. Carrillo et al. [31], reported that PdO nanoparticles can trap mobile Pt species under oxidizing atmosphere and prevent Pt sintering in bimetallic Pt-Pd catalysts. The difference in driving patterns between automobiles and motorcycles results in exhaust gases with different compositions and temperatures. Motorcycle catalytic converters under-study are exposed to lower temperatures and emit very low nitrogen oxide (NOx) concentrations, so it is important to evaluate the activity and aging of motorcycle catalysts under their relevant operating conditions. The performance of motorcycle catalysts, including TWCs [32–35] and oxidation catalysts [3,36–38], has been evaluated in some studies. Small changes in the aging temperature were found to have large impacts on the monolithic catalyst performance in motorcycle applications. Elevation in aging temperature has a more significant impact on CO conversion compared to the addition of oil poisons [9]. Another study focused on the effects of aging temperature and aging time on the thermal deactivation of metallic Pt/Pd/Rh honeycomb motorcycle catalytic converters. Growth in the crystallites due to the washcoat sintering of the aged catalysts was reported as the main cause of catalyst deactivation. The loss of specific surface area and the increase in pore size caused by the sintering were strongly temperature-dependent [39]. A study of the hydrothermal stability of an Rh-based three-way catalyst as a motorcycle emission control device suggested that severe aggregation and transformation of the oxidation state of Rh species into an inactive RhO2 state after aging are the main reasons for severe deactivation [32]. Increasing the air-fuel ratio, as an important parameter affecting catalyst activity, or injecting secondary air to the exhaust gas upstream of the motorcycle oxidation catalyst can improve catalyst conversion and reduce CO and unburned HCs emissions [40–42]. Various catalyst structures such as ceramic structures [35,43], corrugated metals [41,44], and metallic honeycomb monoliths have been utilized in motorcycle-application studies. However, research studies on oxidation catalysts with wiremesh structures are very limited. The wiremesh structure, as a novel technology, has an advantage over other metallic structures, including corrugated metals and metallic monoliths. It is knitted from the stainless steel as a heat resistant wire and is able to trap and oxidize the volatile, particulate compounds and oil droplets efficiently. Wiremesh catalyst can move the particle size distribution to lower sizes, the integral particle counts stay approximately unchanged, but the values of PM emissions due to its filtration functionality are reduced by more than 50% [45]. The wiremesh structure also facilitates heat distribution because of its large thermal conductivity and prevents occurrence of hotspots in the catalyst due to the progress of exothermic reactions. Therefore, the wiremesh structure has more efficient heat distribution than conventional monolithic structures. To the best of our knowledge, the effect of hydrothermal aging on the properties and activity of Pt-Pd-based catalysts in motorcycle-relevant applications has not been studied in previous works. The possible correlations between the activity of the aged wiremesh catalyst and its properties have not yet been elucidated. In the present work, oxidation of CO and C3H6 (as a representative hydrocarbon) over a commercial Pt-Pd/Al2O3/CeO2/ZrO2 catalyst with a wiremesh structure is studied in a flow reactor set-up using temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) experiments. Four different hydrothermal aging procedures were carried out to investigate the effect of aging on the catalyst's activity. Due to the significant role of air-fuel ratio in the wiremesh catalyst activity toward CO and C3H6 oxidation [41], its effect on the activity of the fresh and aged samples was examined. Catalyst characterization using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET), and Energy-Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) was performed to study the effect of various aging conditions on particle morphology, particle size, specific surface area, noble metal loading, and oxidation state of PGM in the samples. Finally, correlations between the properties and activity of the aged catalyst were presented. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst characterization A commercial oxidation catalyst (Pt−Pd/CeO2 −ZrO2 −Al2O3), developed by an industrial catalyst manufacturer as a motorcycle aftertreatment system, was used in this study. The catalyst substrate is woven stainless steel wire over which the active phase is washcoated. The initial canned sample is a cylindrical shape of 5.6 cm diameter and 8 cm length with a total wire surface of about 0.12 m2 and wire diameter of 0.35 mm as shown in Fig. 1a. The FE-SEM image of a small piece of the sample is presented in Fig. 1b in which the washcoat powder coated on the metal substrate can be observed. The catalyst washcoat contains Pt and Pd (Pt:Pd weight ratio of 4:1) as active metals and CeO2, ZrO2, and Al2O3 as a mixed metal oxide support. The BET surface area of the washcoat and total pore volume are 89.63 m2/g and, 0.32 cm3/g, respectively. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis was performed on the fresh and aged samples with wiremesh structure. Pt and Pd loading of the wiremesh sample in the fresh and different aged states are presented in Table 1. Concentration of the main metallic elements of the washcoat (i.e. Pt, Pd, Al, Ce, and Zr) obtained from the ICP-OES analysis are also presented in Table S1 in the supporting information. A BELSORP device model MINI II was utilized to determine the specific surface area and porosity of the fresh and aged samples. The degassing process was performed at 120 °C for 2 h. The nitrogen uptake and desorption tests were then carried out at − 196 °C. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis was employed in order to calculate the specific surface area. The total volume of the pores was obtained from the desorption isotherms. The morphology of the fresh and aged samples was analyzed using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM). A MIRA III-LMU, TESCAN instrument equipped with SE and BSD detectors at a voltage of 30 kV and a resolution of 5 nm was used in the FE-SEM analysis. Pt/Pd particle size (surface-average particle size) was calculated based on FE-SEM images using a sphere model. ImageJ software was used for FE-SEM image processing and calculation of the individual Pt/Pd particles area. Particle diameter was estimated based on Eq. (1) [12]. (1) d p = ∑ n i d i 3 / ∑ n i d i 2 where dp represents the FE-SEM surface-average particle size, di is the diameter of individual particles in the FE-SEM image, and ni is the number of particles of size di. The average particle size was calculated for the fresh sample and aged samples based on size measurement for at least 360 particles. Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping images of Pd and Pt elements were obtained for the fresh and aged samples using an Oxford Instruments EDS Microanalysis equipment, equipped with an X-MAX-80 detector with 20 kV of electron accelerating voltage. ASTM E1508–12a Standard Guide was used for Quantitative Analysis by Energy-Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS). The results of the Pd and Pt EDS analysis are presented in Fig. S2 and S3 in the supporting information. The catalysts composition and electronic structure of the fresh and aged samples with wiremesh structure were investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). A BESTEC (EA 10) electron spectrometer instrument equipped with an achromatic MgKα radiation with a photon energy of 1253.6 eV was used for the XPS analysis. The samples were prepared by securing the wiremesh samples onto double-sided carbon sticky tape. The XPS main chamber was evacuated to 10−10 Torr. The binding energies (BE) of surface species were determined with an accuracy of ± 0.1 eV and calibrated using C1s peak at 285.0 eV. Origin software was used for peak deconvolution and analysis of the spectral data. 2.2 Reactor system A schematic representation of the reactor setup is shown in Fig. S4 in the supporting information. The simulated exhaust gas mixture was produced using high purity gas cylinders. Five mass flow controllers (MFCs) were employed to adjust different gas flow rates and produce desired feed gas concentrations. Required steam for running the aging tests was introduced using a temperature-controlled bubbler by directing the N2 flow through it as a carrier gas. In the tests run under dry conditions, a three-way valve was used to direct the N2 flow to the feed manifold without passing through the bubbler. The inlet and outlet gas lines were wrapped with heating tapes and insulation tapes to keep the line temperatures above 140 ℃ in order to avoid water condensation within the system and improve temperature uniformity of the catalyst. The reactor consisted of a cylindrical quartz tube placed in a temperature-controlled furnace. A cylindrical piece of the wiremesh catalyst, with a diameter of 1.9 cm and length of 1.1 cm, was cut from the commercial sample and used in the reactor tests. In order to extract samples with approximately the same weight and washcoat loading, the samples were cut out from the central point of the wiremesh catalyst with approximately the same length, diameter, and extent of compactness. Mineral wool was wrapped around the sample to block space between the catalyst and quartz tube walls and to prevent gas bypass around the catalyst. The catalyst sample was then loaded inside the quartz tube reactor with internal diameter of 21 mm. Two K-type thermocouples were inserted inside the quartz tube reactor for temperature measurements at two different positions: (1) 1 cm upstream of the inlet face of the catalyst to measure the inlet gas temperature; (2) inside the wiremesh catalyst close to its back face to monitor the sample temperature. Outlet gas concentrations of CO, C3H6, and CO2 were measured using a Henan Oceanus OC-1000 gas detector. Feed gas concentration was also measured by flowing the inlet gas through bypass. The frequency of gas concentration measurement was 1 Hz. The outlet gas concentrations and temperatures in the reactor tube were continuously recorded on a PC. 2.3 Aging and activity tests procedures C3H6 was used as a representative for hydrocarbons in the simulated exhaust gas during reactor tests. Since the majority of Tehran’s motorcycle fleet have four-stroke 125 cc displacement volume, spark-ignited, gasoline-fueled engines with a carburetor fueling system with significant CO and HC emissions [46], 125 cc-engine motorcycles were selected as a representative of Tehran’s motorcycle fleet. Emission data of these motorcycles were used to define the operating conditions of the catalyst activity tests. Due to the ultra-rich combustion of the motorcycles under-study, the amount of NOx emission is very low (i.e. NOx mole fraction in the exhaust gas is within 0.005–0.030%), while CO mole fraction is within 1.8–8.0% and total hydrocarbon mole fraction is within 0.17–0.83%. Therefore, the catalyst activity toward oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons (as the main exhaust pollutants) was evaluated in this study. The CO and C3H6 concentration ranges were selected based on the exhaust gas data of 125 cc gasoline carburetor motorcycles. Considering the ultra-rich combustion (lambda’s as low as 0.6–0.7) of the motorcycles under-study and the beneficial effect of oxygen on the activity of a similar wiremesh oxidation catalyst [41], all TPO experiments were run under different air-fuel ratios representing rich, stoichiometric and lean conditions. Lambda (λ) is the ratio of the operating air-fuel ratio (AFR) to the stoichiometric AFR as shown in Eq. (2) [47]: (2) λ= AFR/AFRstoich After loading each sample into the reactor, the sample was degreened at 550 ℃ for 2 h in 1% O2, 5% H2O, balance N2. The degreening procedure was conducted for all the newly-loaded fresh samples prior to running the reactor tests. Activity of the fresh and aged catalysts was evaluated using temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) experiments. All the TPO tests were run using a ramp rate of 5 °C/min from 150 °C to 600 °C. Table 2 shows the inlet gas compositions for each set of experiments. All the experiments and aging procedures were conducted at the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 25000 h−1 corresponding to the total flow rate of 1.3 L/min. CO and C3H6 co-oxidation tests were carried out on the fresh and aged samples. For the sake of comparison, individual CO and C3H6 oxidation tests were also run on the fresh samples. The light-off tests were run in the absence of H2O and CO2 in the feed. While the absence of CO2 is not expected to significantly impact oxidation results, H2O can affect CO and C3H6 oxidation activity. However, to simplify the reaction mixture and minimize the effect of water gas shift and steam reforming reactions, TPO experiments were run without inlet H2O with the goal of avoiding complexities in data interpretation and focusing on the catalyst activity toward CO and propylene oxidation as the key reactions of interest. A blank test was run by loading mineral wool with no catalyst bed to ensure that the mineral wool does not have any activity. The pressure drop through the catalyst bed was also measured which was below 2 mbar. In the first set of experiments, the effect of the air-fuel ratio on the fresh catalyst activity was evaluated by running TPO experiments for individual CO oxidation, individual propylene oxidation, and co-oxidation of CO and propylene. Individual and co-oxidation tests were run under lambda values of 0.6 (ultra-rich), 0.8 (rich), 1.0 (stoichiometric) and 1.2 (lean). Considering the ultra-rich condition of motorcycles under-study, the two lambda values of 0.6 and 0.8 within the rich range were employed in the first set of experiments to better quantify the impact of oxygen deficiency on catalyst activity. In the second set of experiments, the effect of aging atmosphere and temperature on the wiremesh catalyst activity was studied. To obtain an accurate baseline for making comparison between the activity of the fresh and aged samples and account for small light-off temperature variations originating from the small changes in catalyst size upon changing the samples, the TPO test for co-oxidation of CO and propylene was first conducted on each fresh sample at the three lambda values of 0.7 (as an intermediate value between 0.6 and 0.8), 1.0 and 1.2. Then, the hydrothermal aging procedure was run under various operating conditions. The aging protocol consisted of heating the catalyst to the desired aging temperature under N2, followed by flowing either an oxidizing mixture, i.e. 16% O2, 10% H2O, balanced with N2, or a reducing mixture, i.e. 1% H2, 10% H2O, balanced with N2, over the catalyst for 8 h. Each aging protocol was conducted at two different temperatures, i.e. 750 ℃ and 900 ℃, corresponding to equivalent mileage of approximately 1250 km and 11000 km based on the General Motors RAT-A equation [48], respectively. Thus, the four different aging procedures were as follows: (1) Oxidizing atmosphere at 750 ℃, (2) Reducing atmosphere at 750 ℃, (3) Oxidizing atmosphere at 900 ℃, (4) Reducing atmosphere at 900 ℃. After aging, the water flow was turned off and the nitrogen flow was switched directly to the reactor feed manifold (instead of going through the bubbler) and the reactor was maintained at the aging temperature for 20 min to desorb the remaining moisture from the catalyst. The sample was then cooled down to room temperature without any further changes in the inlet composition. To stabilize the state of catalyst and improve data reproducibility, an oxidative pretreatment was run after each aging protocol and prior to the TPO tests by flowing 10% O2 in N2 at 550 ℃ over the aged sample for 2 h. According to our preliminary data, running either oxidizing or reducing pretreatment at 550/350 ℃ in the absence of water did not affect conversion profiles over the aged samples. The light-off test for co-oxidation of CO and propylene was run over the aged samples at the three different lambda values. The data reproducibility was verified by repeating all the experiments. For this purpose, for all the TPO tests run under lean, stoichiometric, and rich conditions, the activity tests were repeated for the second time on the same sample. The repeated light-off profiles were overlaid with their corresponding first-run profiles indicating data reproducibility. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization results The particle size and morphology of metallic phase on the catalyst surface are important factors affecting oxidation catalysts activity. FE-SEM images of the fresh samples were taken after degreening procedure (as described in Section 2.3) so as to represent the corresponding state of the fresh sample used in the reactor tests. Low-magnification FE-SEM images of the fresh and hydrothermally aged catalysts are shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2c indicates that upon aging at 750 °C under oxidizing condition, some changes occur in the catalyst morphology where slab shape particles appeared compared to the nearly spherical shapes of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 2a). The samples aged at 900 °C (Figs. 2d and 2e) displayed more severe sintering compared to the samples aged at 750 °C. Particle size distribution for the fresh and aged samples were obtained using FE-SEM images with 200 k magnification and are presented in Fig. 3. Here, FE-SEM was used to get a sense of the extent of particle size growth (regardless of metal particles or support) upon different aging conditions. Particle size distribution of the fresh sample is in the range of 6–24 nm and average particle size is 15.7 nm (Fig. 3a). After aging at 750 °C under oxidizing and reducing atmosphere, the average particle size increased to 29.9 nm (Figs. 3c) and 20.9 nm (Fig. 3b), respectively. The extent of increase in particle size was greater at the higher aging temperature (900 °C). Oxidizing-aging at 900 °C, led to the surface-average particle size of 58.8 nm with a broader particle distribution (Fig. 3e) indicating severe sintering when compared with 39.9 nm average size after reducing-aging at 900 °C (Fig. 3d). Regardless of the aging temperature, oxidizing atmosphere sintered the catalyst more severely than reducing atmosphere. Platinum, as the main active phase of the catalyst, has a dominating role in determining the overall catalyst properties. Under oxidative environment, platinum is normally covered with a very thin film of oxide. The vapor pressure of Pt oxides is higher than that of Pd oxides, therefore the degree of catalyst sintering is higher in the Pt-based catalysts under oxidizing conditions. Increasing platinum or palladium particle sizes can adversely affect catalytic performance due to the reduced available surface area [13,47,49,50]. In addition to the particles size of the active metals (i.e. Pt or Pd), oxidation state of active phase plays a crucial role on the catalytic activity. Metallic Pt is generally regarded as the most active phase for oxidation reactions and it is favorable to have a high content of Pt0 on the surface [21], [51,52]. PdO is considered as the more active phase of palladium in oxidation reactions [53]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was used to investigate the impact of hydrothermal aging on the oxidation state of platinum and palladium, as the active phase of the catalyst, in the fresh and aged samples. The Pt4f core level spectra revealed that platinum is present in three oxidation states: Pt0, Pt2+ and Pt4+. The photoelectron spectra of Pt4f for the fresh and aged catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. The 4 f7/2 peak at 70.9 eV and the 4 f5/2 peak at 74.1 eV were assigned to Pt0 representing metallic platinum particles [54]. The binding energies at 73.7 and 77.1 eV were associated with Pt2+ species from PtO phase [55]. The feature at 74.9 eV was attributed to 4 f7/2 peak of Pt4+ from PtO2 phase [17,56]. According to the literature [57,58], palladium supported on Al2O3 may exist in three forms (Pd0, PdO and PdO2) or a combination thereof in the Pd3d core level. As shown in Fig. 5, the obtained results for the fresh and aged catalysts show that the Pd3d core level spectra is present in three oxidation states—Pd0, Pd2+ and Pd4+. The binding energies in the range 336.9–337.2 eV indicated the presence of PdO [59]. The binding energies at 334.9 and 335.1 eV in the photoelectron spectra were assigned to Pd0 species from metal palladium particles [58,59]. A third component at 338.6–339.3 eV was associated with Pd4+ from PdO2 phase [57]. Surface concentration of various Pt species can be obtained using Eq. (3): (3) Pt n ( % ) = ∑ i n ( i + 1 ) n S i n / ∑ 1 6 S i ( n = 0 , + 2 , + 4 ) where Si represents the area under each Pt-related peak and Si n is the area under the Ptn peak. n is the oxidation state of platinum. A similar equation was used to calculate different surface concentration of various Pd species. The contribution of Pt0, Pt2+, Pt4+, Pd0, Pd2+, and Pd4+ on the surface of fresh and aged samples was calculated based on the XPS results and the results are presented in Table 1. The relative surface contribution of Pt0 and Pd2+ on the fresh sample was 57.7% and 58.9%, respectively, demonstrating the highest content of Pt metallic phase and PdO species among all samples. The high content of the more active Pt0 and Pd2+ on the fresh sample can facilitate CO and C3H6 oxidation. Concentration of Pt2+ (i.e. PtO phase) is 42.3% and the Pt4+ (PtO2) peak was not observed on the fresh sample spectra. The substantial content of PtO is probably due to the fresh sample exposure to degreening conditions (i.e. in the presence of O2 and steam at 550 °C) and the role of the oxygen storage components of the support (such as ceria) in providing oxygen for PtO formation. Upon aging at 750 °C under reducing and oxidizing conditions, the relative contribution of Pt0 decreased to 40.2% and 35.8%, respectively, and the Pt4+ peak appeared in the spectra. Oxidizing condition facilitates oxidation of Pt and increases the Pt4+ content on the surface relative to that under reducing condition. Formation of PtO and PtO2 phases at 750 °C is going to negatively impact CO/C3H6 conversion over the aged samples. The relative contribution of Pd0 and Pd4+ (PdO2) on the fresh sample is 4.6% and 36.5%, respectively. According to the literature [13], formation of stable Pd4+ species on the catalyst may also contribute to the reaction, leading to an increase in the catalytic activity. Upon aging at 750 °C, the relative concentration of Pd2+ (the most active phase of palladium) decreased to 41.5% and 45.6% under reducing and oxidizing conditions, respectively. As shown in Figs. 4d-e and 5d-e, with increasing the aging temperature up to 900 °C, the intensity of XPS spectra for both noble metals was significantly suppressed indicating partial Pt and Pd loss at such high temperatures. This result is in agreement with our results from ICP-OES analysis, presented in Table 1, where up to 8.5% Pt and 14.4% Pd loss were observed in the samples aged at 900 °C. In the aged sample under oxidizing atmosphere at 900 °C, the intensity of all Pt- and Pd-related peaks has significantly decreased, except the Pt4+ peak at approximately 75 eV (Fig. 4e). This indicates PtO2 domination on the surface. The surface contribution of the most active phase of palladium, Pd2+, in different samples decreases in the following order: fresh sample > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > reducing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C > reducing-aged at 900 °C. However, the order for Pt0 (as the most active phase of platinum) is: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C ≈ reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. These results indicate that, upon reducing-aging protocols, lower extent of Pt0 oxidation to Ptn+ occurs compared to the oxidizing aging protocols. This is expected to be beneficial for achieving higher oxidation activities as it preserves the most active Pt0 state. Note that the decrease observed in the relative content of Pt0 after reducing aging can be due to the presence of water that can act as an oxygen source at high temperatures. According to the overall trend observed for Pd2+ (as will be shown in Fig. 8c), at each aging temperature, Pd2+ fraction under oxidizing condition is higher than that under reducing condition. The extent of decrease in Pd2+ contribution extremely depends on the aging temperature rather than aging atmosphere. The reason for such behavior is the presence of CeO2 and ZrO2 in the support. Due to the good interaction between Pd and Ce-Zr-O, the mobility of active oxygen from Ce-Zr to Pd can readily stabilize PdO species regardless of reducing or oxidizing conditions [58]. The values of BET surface area, total pore volume, and noble metal concentration of the fresh and aged samples with the wiremesh structure are listed in Table 1. Note that the low values reported for surface area and pore volume is due to the nature of wiremesh sample, where coated metallic substrate has been used in the BET analysis (not washcoat powder by itself). The specific surface area of the fresh wiremesh sample is 20.07 m2/g. After aging at 750 °C, the BET surface area of the sample decreases by 13.3% and 24.0% under reducing and oxidizing conditions, respectively. After aging at 900 °C, the surface area significantly drops by 54.4% and 64.0% under reducing and oxidizing conditions, respectively. Similar trend in observed for pore volume of the sample which decreases by increasing the aging temperature. The pore volume and BET surface area of the samples decrease in the following order: fresh sample > Reducing-aged at 750 ℃ > Oxidizing-aged at 750 ℃ > Reducing-aged at 900 ℃ > Oxidizing-aged at 900 ℃. These results indicate dramatic structural changes and sintering occurred during hydrothermal aging at high temperature that can play role in activity loss of the aged samples. Vaporization of the noble metals at high temperatures is one of the reasons for catalyst deactivation. According to the literature [60], Pt is more easily vaporized than Pd, but the combination of two PGMs makes the platinum more resistant against vaporization. The ICP results in Table 1 show that, upon aging at 750 °C, the noble metal loading (i.e. Pt and Pd) decreased such that up to 3.4% and 8.5% decrease occurred in Pt and Pd concentration, respectively, after oxidizing aging at 750 °C. For the catalysts aged at 900 °C, the Pt concentration decreased by 8.5% under oxidizing condition and the Pd concentration decreased by 14.4% after reducing aging. In summary, hydrothermal aging led to decreased surface area and partial loss of noble metals due to vaporization, as confirmed by the ICP and XPS results in this study. This phenomena becomes more pronounced at higher aging temperatures and can remarkably aggravate the extent of catalyst deactivation. 3.2 CO and propylene oxidation over the fresh catalyst Co-oxidation of CO and propylene over a fresh wiremesh sample was performed as a measure of initial activity of the catalyst. The mutual effects of CO and propylene on the oxidation reactions were also studied. The experiments were run under lean, stoichiometric, rich and ultra-rich conditions using lambda values of 1.2, 1.0, 0.8, and 0.6, respectively. CO and propylene conversion profiles as a function of inlet gas temperature are presented in Fig. 6 where solid lines represent co-oxidation profiles. Similar tests were run for individual oxidation of CO and propylene. For comparison, the corresponding individual oxidation profiles are also displayed in Fig. 6 using dashed lines. As shown in Fig. 6, the presence of both reactants in the feed gas resulted in the shift of all light-off curves toward higher temperatures with respect to the corresponding individual oxidation profiles. Such a shift is due to the mutual inhibition effects of CO and C3H6 on their oxidation activity, consistent with the previous results in the literature [61–63]. Competitive adsorption of reactants on either Pt or Pd active sites as well as surface intermediates are the reasons for such mutual inhibition. Each CO molecule normally requires one Pt or Pd active site for adsorption and segmentation into smaller species, whereas each C3H6 molecule requires multiple active sites [63]. CO and propylene also limit oxygen adsorption and dissociation onto the surface and this competitive step is facilitated as temperature increases. At the early stages of light off, due to the relative abundance of adsorbed CO compared to C3H6 surface intermediates, the probability of CO reaction with adsorbed oxygen is higher. Upon the progress of exothermic CO oxidation, temperature further increases and the number of available active sites for C3H6 adsorption and oxidation obviously increases. At this stage, CO profile decelerates due to the inhibition effects of propylene-derived surface intermediates (Figs. 6a and 6b). The appearance of the low slope region in the 210–260 °C range in the CO oxidation profile during co-oxidation is clearly visible under the lean and stoichiometric conditions (Figs. 6a and 6b) indicating the inhibition effects of propylene-derived surface intermediates [61]. According to the literature [61,62], the scission of adsorbed propylene on catalyst surface leads to formation of intermediate species such as ethylene, acetate and formats. This in turn leads to appearance of inhibition steps on CO conversion profiles. Note that the initial ignition of CO during co-oxidation is close to that during individual CO oxidation. Propylene-derived intermediates form after CO ignition by utilizing the CO oxidation exotherm. With further increase in temperature, the heat required for desorption/reaction of surface species is provided and the inhibition steps are followed by accelerated progress of CO and propylene conversion. Under rich and ultra-rich conditions, the nearly flat region is gradually dissipated and only appears as slight inflection points on CO conversion profiles at λ = 0.8 and λ = 0.6. The reason for gradual disappearance of the lower slope region under rich and ultra-rich conditions, is that these intermediates are stable below 250 °C and start to desorb/convert at higher temperatures where the rich and ultra-rich conversion profiles are located. During individual and co-oxidation tests, complete conversion of CO is achieved under stoichiometric (Fig. 6a) and lean conditions (Fig. 6b). However, under oxygen-deficient atmospheres (Figs. 6c and 6d), i.e. lambda values of 0.8 and 0.6, complete CO conversion was not attained even at high temperatures. At these lambda values, final CO conversion in the presence of propylene is higher than the corresponding values in the CO-only experiments. The reason for such higher conversion is that in the simultaneous presence of both reactants, CO ignition starts prior to C3H6 ignition. Therefore during co-oxidation tests, higher fraction of the limited oxygen content in the feed gas is available to react with CO, and higher level of final CO conversion is attained compared to that of the individual CO oxidation. Comparison between individual and co-oxidation profiles indicates that by introducing the second reactant to the feed, a greater shift toward higher temperatures is seen for CO conversion profile compared to propylene profile. For example, CO T50 (i.e. the temperature at which CO conversion is 50%) increases about 42 °C while propylene T50 increases about 9 °C during co-oxidation under stoichiometric condition (as shown in Table 3 and Fig. S5 in the supporting information). As such, C3H6 hindrance toward CO oxidation is more significant than CO hindrance toward C3H6 oxidation due to the substantial negative impact of propylene-derived intermediates. Since CO has also blocked some of the surface sites, the easier oxidation of these species leads to earlier CO light-off. The CO inhibition effect on propylene oxidation becomes more severe as O2 concentration decreases. Under lean and stoichiometric conditions (i.e. Figs. 6a and 6b), the ignition slopes for CO and propylene after inhibition steps were generally steeper compared to the rich and ultra-rich conditions. Therefore, complete conversion of CO and propylene was attainable at relatively lower temperatures when sufficient amount of oxygen was available. The best performance was achieved at λ = 1.2 where almost complete conversion of both reactants was attained at 310 °C. As such, the catalyst performance ranking for co-oxidation of CO and propylene under different air-fuel ratios is: λ = 1.2 > 1 > 0.8 > 0.6. 3.3 Effect of aging on catalyst activity 3.3.1 Aging under reducing condition The effect of various aging conditions on catalyst performance was evaluated by running activity tests under lean, stoichiometric and rich condition (i.e. corresponding to lambda values of 1.2, 1.0, and 0.7, respectively). Fig. 7(a, c, and e) shows CO and propylene light-off curves after aging the sample under reducing atmosphere at 750 ℃ and 900 ℃ at the three lambda values. CO and propylene conversion profiles for the fresh sample, performed prior to each aging procedure, are also shown on the plots with dashed lines (denoted as F in the legend). Decreasing the air-fuel ratio has shifted CO and propylene light-off profiles to higher temperatures, similar to the results observed for the fresh samples. Regardless of air-fuel ratio condition, aging under reducing condition led to shift of conversion profiles toward higher temperatures. The higher the aging temperature, the higher the extent of this shift to the right. Under lean and stoichiometric conditions (Fig. 7a-d), where sufficient oxygen is available, CO and C3H6 conversion profiles overlay with each other at ca. 50% conversion due to the desorption/reaction of surface intermediates and the availability of active sites for propylene oxidation. A different trend is observed under the oxygen-deficient atmosphere (i.e. λ = 0.7, Figs. 7e and 7f) where propylene oxidation experiences a delay after CO light-off and a gap between CO and C3H6 TPO profiles is seen for all samples. In addition, a more significant decay in the slope of propylene conversion profiles is observed as aging conditions become more severe. Under rich conditions, the appearance of the lower slope region becomes less significant over the fresh and aged samples. In order to make a comparison between changes in T50 and T10′s under lean, stoichiometric, and rich conditions after various hydrothermal aging conditions, Fig. S5 is presented in the supporting information. A clearly distinct trend is observed in the final parts of CO and C3H6 conversion profiles over the aged samples at the lambda value of 0.7 (Fig. 7e). In the high temperature range (above 350 °C for the 750 °C-aged sample and above 380 °C for the 900 °C-aged sample), CO conversion becomes descending and propylene conversion continuously increases over both aged samples. The reason is the progress of steam reforming reactions and partial oxidation of propylene, as undesired side reactions, over the aged samples under an extremely oxygen-deficient atmosphere. Our data indicate that at the high temperature, CO2 concentration at the reactor outlet remains constant (data not shown) when propylene conversion is ascending and CO conversion is decaying (Fig. 7e). Once a substantial amount of CO has been reacted and very small oxygen concentration is available, there is a competition between CO and C3H6 for consuming the remaining oxygen. Under such conditions, steam reforming reaction and partial oxidation of propylene proceed and CO oxidation to CO2 is suppressed. Therefore, the extra CO emission produced by steam reforming and partial oxidation of C3H6 results in lower CO conversions. The progress of C3H6 partial oxidation is insignificant in the earlier stages of light off. These results are in line with the previous studies where partial oxidation of C3H6 has been reported to occur on Pt-based catalysts above 400 °C under the rich condition [36–38]. 3.3.2 Aging under oxidizing condition CO and C3H6 light-off curves for the fresh and aged samples with aging under the oxidizing condition at 750 ℃ and 900 ℃ is shown in Fig. 6. Different panels indicate the test results at three different lambda values, i.e. 1.2, 1.0 and 0.7. Under all air-fuel ratios, the conversion profiles of the aged samples are shifted toward higher temperatures, with the shift becoming more significant as the aging temperature increases from 750 °C to 900 °C. Comparison between Fig. 7(a, c, e) and Fig. 7(b, d, f) at corresponding lambda values indicates that the extent of shift toward higher temperatures due to oxidizing-aging is greater than that due to reducing-aging. At lambda values of 1.0 and 1.2 (Fig. 7b and d), the lower slope region in CO conversion profiles of the aged samples becomes less significant compared to the fresh one. According to these results, surface inhibition effects gradually disappear by shifting the light-off curves to higher temperatures, whether the reason for this shift is oxygen deficiency in the reaction mixture or hydrothermal aging of the catalyst. Other features of the conversion profiles of the oxidizing-aged samples are similar to the results reported for the samples aged under a reducing atmosphere (Fig. 7a and c). According to these results, switching the catalyst condition from rich toward lean atmosphere can partially compensate the deactivation impacts of hydrothermal aging by moving the light-off curves toward lower temperatures. Therefore, injecting secondary air to the exhaust gas upstream of the catalyst (and downstream of the combustion chamber) can result in an overall improvement in CO and propylene conversion with respect to the catalyst performance under its normal operating condition (i.e. rich mode). 3.3.3 Correlation between catalyst properties and activity The extent of catalyst deactivation was analyzed as a function of catalyst properties including average particle size and oxidation state of all species in active phase (i.e. Pt and Pd). Since CO and C3H6 T50 are correlated with each other, CO T50 was used as a measure of catalyst activity for oxidation reactions where the lower T50′s indicate higher activities. Correlation between either CO or C3H6 T50 and average particle size is shown in Fig. 8a. indicating a linear relationship between these two parameters (with R2 equal to 0.99). The extent of activity loss (i.e. increase in T50) and the particle size of the samples increase in the following order: fresh sample < reducing-aged at 750 °C < oxidizing-aged at 750 °C < reducing-aged at 900 °C < oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. These results show that the most severe deactivation occurs at 900 °C under oxidizing atmosphere. At each aging temperature employed, higher degree of catalyst sintering occurred under oxidizing atmosphere compared to the reducing one. Sintering of Pt and Pd has been reported as an important reason for dramatic deactivation of TWCs after aging at 900 °C [64–69]. The extent of deactivation can also be correlated with variations of either the most active state of the Pt or Pd phase on the surface. Previous studies have shown that metallic Pt [51] and PdO [53] are the main active phase for oxidation reactions over Pt-Pd catalysts. Pd-based catalysts deactivate significantly under reducing atmosphere compared to the oxidizing atmosphere [70], while Pt-based catalysts substantially lose their activity under oxidizing conditions [71]. Considering our catalyst formulation (i.e. Pt:Pd ratio 4:1), it is expected that Pt sites play a dominating role in catalyst deactivation behavior. According to the XPS results presented in Table 1, Ptn+ content for the fresh, 750-oxidizing, and 900-oxidizing aged catalysts are 42.3, 64.3, and 80.8, respectively, while Pt0 for these samples are 57.7, 35.8, and 19.3, respectively. Therefore, upon oxidizing aging, the contribution of oxidized states of platinum (i.e. Pt2+ and Pt4+) increases at the expense of metallic Pt. The variation of CO oxidation T50 as a function of metallic Pt content (i.e. Pt0), Pd2+ content (representing PdO as the most active state of palladium), and average particle size of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 8a. Data points are related to the fresh and aged samples under different conditions. There is a linear, negative correlation between CO T50 and the relative contribution of Pt0 sites. Similar negative correlation is also observed between CO T50 and the relative contribution of Pd2+ sites. A very strong positive correlation between CO T50 and average particle size of the catalyst is also observed in Fig. 8a. C3H6 T50 variations with these three catalyst properties indicate trends similar to CO T50 (data not shown for brevity). These results indicate that preserving the higher content of Pt0 and Pd2+ on the catalyst surface and smaller particle size are beneficial for representing high activity toward CO and propylene oxidation reactions. Effect of aging conditions on CO oxidation T50 (vertical axis), metallic Pt content (obtained from XPS analysis and represented in horizontal axis) and average particle size of the catalyst (obtained from FE-SEM analysis) is represented in Fig. 8b. A similar plot with Pd2+ contribution values as the horizontal axis is also shown in Fig. 8c. Bubble sizes correspond to average particle size of the catalyst and the labels next to each bubble indicate average particle sizes in nm. It is worth mentioning that the plot of CO T50 as a function of Pt0, Pd2+, and particle size under other air-fuel ratios, i.e. the lean and rich conditions, follows a trend similar to stoichiometric condition, Fig. 8b and Fig. 8c (data is not shown for brevity). According to Fig. 8b, contribution of metallic Pt in different samples decreases in the following order: fresh sample > reducing-aging at 750 °C ≈ reducing-aging at 900 °C > oxidizing-aging at 750 °C > oxidizing-aging at 900 °C. On the other hand, the order of decrease in the PdO content, shown in Fig. 8c, is: fresh sample > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > reducing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C > reducing-aged at 900 °C. Considering catalyst formulation (Pt:Pd of 4:1), the extent of catalyst activity is expected to be mainly governed by the Pt oxidation state. The results presented in Fig. 8b suggest that oxidizing atmosphere at the higher aging temperature (i.e. 900 °C) can substantially exacerbate extent of deactivation due to the significant particle growth associated with lower contribution of Pt0 sites. In contrast, reducing-aging with H2 limits oxidation of platinum sites [69] thereby preserves metallic Pt and results in less deactivation even at 900 °C. It can be seen in Fig. 8c that increasing aging temperature leads to the decrease in PdO (i.e. Pd2+) fraction thus increases CO T50. The effect of aging temperature on the Pd2+ content has been more severe than the aging atmosphere. By increasing the aging temperature, the Pd2+ content has substantially decreased, and this decrease is associated with an increase in the CO T50. At each aging temperature, however, the reducing-aged sample with slightly lower Pd2+ content has a higher activity which is due to the dominating role of Pt state on the overall activity. Using CO T50 as a measure of catalyst activity, it can be concluded that the order of activity in different samples is: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. This ranking is in agreement with the catalyst particle size where the lower size results in higher activity. This ranking also indicates that Pt0 content has a more dominating effect on catalyst activity compared to the Pd2+ content due to the higher content of Pt in catalyst formulation. 4 Conclusions The impact of hydrothermal aging on catalyst particle size, BET surface area, and oxidation state of noble metals was studied. Increasing aging temperature led to a substantial degree of catalyst sintering and particle aggregation resulting in lower BET surface area and a significant particle size growth. At each aging temperature, more significant particle growth was obtained under oxidizing condition compared to reducing one. According to the XPS results, the surface contribution of Pt0, as the most active state of platinum, decreased after hydrothermal aging in the following order: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C ≈ reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. The Pd2+ contribution also decreased by increasing the aging temperature and using an oxidizing atmosphere. According to the CO and propylene oxidation tests over the fresh wiremesh catalyst, decreasing lambda values from 1.2 (lean) toward 0.6 (ultra-rich), shifted CO and propylene light-off profiles toward higher temperatures. The inhibition effects of surface intermediates such as ethylene, formate, and acetate, were clearly observed on CO and propylene co-oxidation profiles under the lean and stoichiometric conditions. A descending trend observed in the final stages of CO light-off over the aged samples under the rich condition was due to the partial oxidation of C3H6 to CO above 340 °C. The low slope region, representing surface inhibition effects, disappears on the light-off profiles over the aged samples due to the shift of light-off curves to a higher temperature range. The disappearance of the inhibition steps was also observed in the light-off curve of the fresh samples under the rich and ultra-rich conditions which was attributed to the stability of surface intermediates up to 250 °C. The extent of catalyst deactivation upon aging showed a linear relationship with the particle size and relative contribution of metallic Pt on the surface. The T50 data over the aged samples revealed that the catalyst activity for both CO and propylene conversion decreases in the following order: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. This order was in agreement with the order of catalyst sintering and particle growth where the highest degree of sintering and particle growth occurred under oxidizing aging at 900 °C. It was found that the reducing atmosphere can alleviate the extent of deactivation compared to the oxidizing atmosphere due to the higher content of metallic Pt and less severe particle growth. The normal operating condition of motorcycles under-study is rich and ultra-rich. Therefore, during thermal excursions,less catalyst deactivation is expected compared to oxidizing environment. On the other hand, when pulse air valves are used in the motorcycle exhaust line for injecting secondary air upstream of the catalyst, oxygen can have a more detrimental impact during thermal excursions (temperatures above 700 °C). However, in this case, the normal operating conditions also shift from ultra-rich to stoichiometric or lean conditions, which can improve catalyst activity even after severe hydrothermal aging due to the positive effect of increasing lambda. Therefore, it is expected that using pulse air valves (i.e. excess O2) can have an overall positive impact on the catalyst activity even after high mileage operation of motorcycles. coredata.dc:description: Motorcycles are major contributors to air pollutants, i.e. CO, VOCs, and PM, emissions to the atmosphere in some regions around the world. Hydrothermal aging of the Pd-Pt-based wiremesh catalyst, as an emission control device for 4-stroke carburetor motorcycles, was studied under laboratory-simulated aging conditions. Aging temperature and reaction atmosphere were selected as independent variables affecting aging. Catalyst properties were characterized by ICP, XPS, BET, EDS, and FE-SEM analysis. Increasing aging temperature and oxidizing atmosphere led to a more pronounced particle size growth and sintering after aging. Regardless of the aging temperature, surface inhibition effects gradually disappeared by shifting the light-off curves to higher temperatures, whether the reason for this shift is oxygen deficiency in the reaction mixture or hydrothermal aging of the catalyst. The surface concentration of the most active phase of platinum, Pt0, decreased in the following order: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C ≈ reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. The overall trend of activity for different samples is as follows: fresh sample > reducing-aged at 750 °C > oxidizing-aged at 750 °C > reducing-aged at 900 °C > oxidizing-aged at 900 °C. The less extent of deactivation under reducing atmosphere was attributed to the preservation of metallic Pt content and limited particle size growth under such aging conditions. Analysis of the effect of the air-fuel ratio on the light-off profiles indicated that under all aging conditions, the rich atmosphere resulted in the highest degree of deactivation compared to stoichiometric and lean conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of hydrothermal aging on CO and C3H6 oxidation over a Pt-Pd-based wiremesh catalyst as a motorcycle aftertreatment device
